title: Warriors' Luke Walton will coach in hometown
text:
Warriors' Luke Walton will coach in hometown By Diamond Leung Posted: 10/16/2015 05:42:03 PM PDT Updated: 10/16/2015 05:42:05 PM PDT OAKLAND -- Luke Walton wasn't sure his father would be watching him coach in his hometown of San Diego on Saturday until Warriors vice president of communications Raymond Ridder let him know. 
"A certain 7-footer has already requested eight tickets," Ridder said. 
Hall of Famer Bill Walton along with Luke's mother, brothers and high school friends are expected to be in attendance when the Warriors face the Los Angeles Lakers in a preseason game at the arena where Luke as a toddler watched his father play. 
The Warriors take on the Lakers at Valley View Casino Center, which for a long time was called the San Diego Sports Arena when it was the home court for Bill and the San Diego Clippers. 
Luke attended high school in San Diego before going on to play eight-plus seasons with the Lakers and win two NBA championships. 
In the season before Luke came to the Warriors, Walton worked as a player development coach for the Lakers' NBA Development League affiliate and as a television analyst covering the Lakers. 
Now Walton will coach against the Lakers' Byron Scott, who was his head coach when he played for the Cleveland Cavaliers. 
"He had a great relationship with his players, and I appreciated that as a player," Walton said. "So I definitely try to use that in my coaching style. Phil (Jackson) was a little more isolated from the players than that. Because as a player I enjoyed my relationship with Coach Scott, I try to do that when I'm out here with these guys." Advertisement 
Walton continues to serve as the interim head coach for the defending champions during a three-game trip to Southern California. Steve Kerr travel with the team, but will not run practices yet, according to Walton. 
"I don't think he wants to do that until he's ready to come back fully because it's just more of a distraction for all the players if he's in and out running practice one day and not the next day," Walton said. "So I think he's just kind of traveling with us, but he's still going to kind of keep his distance a little bit." 
The Warriors will be missing three regular starters against the Lakers. 
Klay Thompson will not be at the game and did not practice Friday while he was traveling to the Bahamas for family funeral services. The Warriors expect him to rejoin the team later on this trip. 
Andrew Bogut will not play after suffering a broken nose in Thursday's preseason win against the Houston Rockets. He is expected to undergo minor surgery to reset his nose after the swelling decreases. 
Harrison Barnes practiced Friday, but was held out of 5-on-0 drills and will miss a second consecutive game because of a bone bruise in his right knee. 
The Warriors will also be missing guard Jarell Eddie, who did not travel after suffering a sprained right ankle against the Rockets. Chris Babb and Ian Clark are the remaining guards with non-guaranteed contracts on the trip. 
Kobe Bryant will not play for the Lakers due to precautionary reasons after experiencing soreness in a left leg muscle, Scott told reporters. 
Walton said he was leaning toward starting Festus Ezeli in place of Bogut after he came off the bench and had five blocked shots against the Rockets. 
"Every time I block a shot, I talk a little smack too, so I like blocking shots," Ezeli said, laughing. 
Walton said Ezeli has improved on making reads, passing and posting. 
"His confidence is high right now," Walton said. "He wants to show everyone what he can do now. For us as a staff, sometimes we've got to remind him, 'Let it come to you. We now know what you can do.' 
"We feel confident with the ball down there in his hands." For more on the Warriors, see the Inside the Warriors blog at www.ibabuzz.com/warriors . Follow Diamond Leung on Twitter at twitter.com/diamond83 .
